title: giant manta ray diver removes fish hooks ningaloo reef western australia
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the options'That manta absolutely understood what was going on. Jake went down again and again and she just remained still for him'Click to followThe IndependentA giant manta ray has been filmed appearing to beg a professional er for help saving her life.The three-metre-wide sea creature is shown swimming up to snorkelling guide Jake Wilton and flipping over in the water – apparently to show him fish hooks embedded in her right eye.The footage, caught near Ningaloo Reef off Western Australia’s north west coast, seems to show the manta ray then staying perfectly still as Mr Wilton gently removes the potentially deadly spikes.The animal – well known to locals and affectionately nicknamed Freckles – then swims away with a flourish as the er emerges triumphantly with the hooks.Monty Halls, a British marine biologist aboard the boat at the time, said: “That manta absolutely understood what was going on. Jake went down again and again and she just remained still for him.”Created with Sketch.Underwater Photographer of the Year Show all 45Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Winner: Behaviour and overall winner. I worry that this image will refuel the public's imbalanced perception of sharks but as an image capturing behaviour it has drama, adrenaline, grace, beauty and finality. That's a very rare combination in one image. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Winner: Wide Angle. The first moment I viewed this image I knew it would be a strong contender. For me it's the symmetry of the Humpback and the balance between the er and calf. Everything about it is in perfect alignment. The shape of the tail in relation to the four corners of the frame, not to mention the position of the free er and calf. Superb imagery at its very best.  Many congratulations Francois. - Martin Edge (Judge)    Winner: Macro. Fabio’s use of long exposure and panning has turned a classic portrait of a Sepiola into an unforgettable one. The sharp and ghosted images of the bobtail squid balance pleasingly in the frame and combined with the outstretched tentacles give the feeling of the cephalopod lunging for its prey. An innovative and most deserving category winner. - Alex Mustard (Judge) It is hard to imagine what it must have been like to have experienced such a large scale natural spectacle as this but this image, perfectly composed and timed, gets close. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Winner: British Waters Macro. A mantra of mine is 'It's not what it is. It's where it is' and this long clawed Squat lobster is in a perfect position to make a memorable image. The author, instead of 'blasting' it with light, has gone in the opposite direction by restricting the strobe into a snooted spotlight in order to illuminate just the features of the lobster and the dainty sea loch anemones. It's an example of 'Isolation lighting' at its very best. A great deal of uw photographers invest their time in what they want to illuminate. This is an example which in my opinion illustrates features that they do not want to illuminate, hence the punchy black background and the soft delicate hues of dark sand, facial features topped off by the sea loch anemones. - Martin Edge (Judge)Winner: Marine Conservation. The problems of plastic pollution and ghost fishing are both illustrated by this struggling loggerhead turtle. I am happy to learn this inidual was lucky enough to survive this deathtrap thanks to the photographer - Alex Mustard (Judge)What a chin, what a forehead, what a character. This picture has portrait written all over it, and such a fascinating species ideally suited to this close focus wide angle approach. - Alex Mustard (Judge) Winner: Portrait. Superb impact from the very first moment it was presented. Perfect composition within the image frame and the understated colours. To top it off the authors comments above say it all... a Smiling Happy Angel's Face. One of my favourites from the entire competition. - Martin Edge (Judge)  Winner: Up &amp Coming. Beautiful split shot with both a perfect under and over split. A very strong favourite with all the judges and one of the best examples I have seen of this type of image for some time. Just Superb! - Martin Edge (Judge)Winner: Black &amp White. It must be 11 out of 10 for this groundbreaking image. Conception, interpretation and perseverance coupled with black and white’s ability to concentrate on the key elements. It gets better with each viewing. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Grey seals are a perennial favourite in UPY as one of the UK's star wildlife attractions. This upside-down portrait is quirky and cute and easily won the affections of the judging panel. Great to see an overseas photographer coming to the UK to show us how it's done! - Alex Mustard (Judge)Winner: Compact. This image was a very popular choice between the panel. Ideal for a split rendition. What makes this a winner for me, not withstanding the double exposure is the sympathetic balance of light &amp colour connected  between the top half and bottom of the image frame. - Martin Edge (Judge)Winner: British Waters Compact. Does British ing get any better than a fun encounter with a grey seal pup? This youngster’s relaxed and curious face is captured perfectly by Martin, making us all want to be there too. - Alex Mustard (Judge)Winner: British Waters Living Together. Images tell stories but well thought out and executed ones speak volumes. This is such an example which feeds the eye with tales of the seaside on summer days, lively marine spectacles and excited human interaction. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)1545 Isles of Scilly, UKWinner: British Waters Wide Angle. Photographers often feel competition shots must be packed with new tricks to win. At UPY we always appreciate classic technique when it raises the bar of what has been done before. Rob's full technicolour wide angle scenic reveals the richness of UK seas with an elegant simplicity that is incredibly challenging to pull off in British conditions. - Alex Mustard (Judge) Winner: Wrecks. So simple yet so powerful the additional lighting of the turret and the main er perfectly positioned. This was a very strong category this year with a deserved winner and it's refreshing to read the acknowledgement to Leigh Bishop's pioneering work. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) The iconic silhouette of a seahorse is a graphically powerful picture. Here Zarina has raised that to another level with the addition of a red filter to her snooted strobe, reminiscent of a rim-lit animal at sunset. - Alex Mustard (Judge) All the judges found this to be probably the most distressing image to view but its uncompromising message must be seen by as many people as possible. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)As a subject we have seen our fair share of these colourful characters but this one shone through and the eggs almost look as if they have been inidually lit! - Peter Rowlands (Judge)Superb image with a perfect line across the split. Good exposure both above and below the water line and such an ideal subject to cap it all off. Excellent work. - Martin Edge (Judge)This is an excellent example for this category. It takes a tried and trusted angle but completely lifts it by using the fabric. It becomes more than an image a concept, a transition, a rebirth. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)2245 Isles of Scilly, UKThis image stood out on many levels. Composition, colour vibrancy and contrast combined with an unusual angle kept us coming back to it and helped it rise in the rankings with each viewing. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)Perfect control of angle, light and focus. This was always up there with all of the judges. A clear favourite just like Nick Park’s genius creations. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) I've seen many images of eel and shrimp around Indonesia, however you have taken this two steps forward. 1) With your excellent idea to snoot the eye and 2) with your backlight on the shrimp. You can expect many photographers to practice your technique in the months to come. Congratulations for your vision. Very well thought out and executed. - Martin Edge (Judge)    It’s not what you’ve got, it’s what you do with it. The split may have been elusive but well worth the effort. This is a deceptively subtle excellent delivery. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)I have witnessed this behaviour from the surface with its high velocity 'testosterone and tonnage' and I remember thinking how happy I was to be in the boat. To have the presence of mind to time this shot whilst one's senses are being bombarded is heroic in my view. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) What an amazing moment. From the expression on the face of the unicornfish fleeing for its life, to the hunting pack of sharks, especially the leader with its mouth snapping open that fan out diagonally across this composition. And that is without considering what a great challenge it is to shoot these images of split second action, in the dead of night, underwater. - Alex Mustard (Judge)  There is so much energy in this image. If you look at it long enough you can begin to see just a hint of movement of all the fish around the coral. The colours are realistic and this top down shot works well.  - Martin Edge (Judge)A jaw-dropping wide angle scene with sharks, rays and mountains. A winning combination in the Up &amp Coming category. - Alex Mustard (Judge)3045 Loch Long, Argyll and ButeThis is a subtle image with light and detail that are a delight to explore. The sunset, trees and underwater scene combine to create a wonderful feeling of the place. We particularly like how the composition allows the line of the shore to be continued underwater by the seaweeds.  - Alex Mustard (Judge)Photographing pike underwater is one thing but finding your own underwater artistic stamp is quite another matter. With this particular image the author has done just that! By using a slow shutter speed of 18th sec and a panning technique from right to left gives the impression of movement whilst the pike is pin sharp. - Martin Edge (Judge)Arthur’s image scores with both its foreground and background. The deadman’s fingers soft coral make an attractive foreground, enhanced by the crab sheltering within, and the striking sunbeams create beauty and atmosphere in the background. I also love the feeling of depth created by the legs of the jetty reaching up for the surface. - Alex Mustard (Judge)In recent UPY competitions UK macro images have lacked their overseas counterpart's flair and imagination but this magnificent shot raises the bar for everyone else to follow. World class from the UK at last. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)Memorable photographs of people underwater are deceptively difficult and require both the photographer and model to be at the top of their game. The simplicity of the composition works to highlight the delicious details in the girl's pose. - Alex Mustard (Judge) This is a timeless scene that communicates a detailed story. The cavern, the silversides sheltering, the tarpon hunting and the er kneeling reverentially, taking it all in. It is a fabulous use of black and white to tell this story of shadows and light. - Alex Mustard (Judge) Sometimes it is the small detail which contributes so much. The white of the eye and the row of teeth in what could be construed as a smile convey mischief and menace in equal measures. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Once again Tobias you have succeeded in capturing one of the most photographed wrecks in the Red Sea and photographing it in a completely different way. You push the boundaries of wreck photography and I congratulate you for your vision and forward thinking of new ideas. - Martin Edge (Judge)  Perfect composition and framed against the stark black background. However it's the contrast of white on black which attracts the eye again and again every time this particular image popped up to greet us. The colour of the nudibranch was sufficiently bright enough to raise our senses again and again as it proceeded through the competition.  The soft delicate treatment of the snooted flash is also very well managed. - Martin Edge (Judge)    This shot puts you right in the picture and records a special encounter in a very special place. Every element contributes and the lucky or intended curve of the split creates great spatial depth. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Symmetry, graphic simplicity and for once in UK waters a black background which contributes to a positive outer worldly delivery. A mould breaker. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) I see and judge many images of the sockeye salmon but this is one of the best. The alignment of the two salmon not to mention the composition within the frame.  The surgy peak of the action is in perfect symmetry with the window which provides the viewer with topside influences of the trees against a vivid blue sky. There is so much image depth in this example. - Martin Edge (Judge)    Such a delicate image yet so full of emotion. There are times when there are no more words needed. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)UPY loves seahorse photos! Especially when they capture a fleeting behaviour, such as this. But we hadn't realised during judging that this was a new species of seahorse, nor did with know the incredible backstory behind this picture, we just loved the moment. - Alex Mustard (Judge)  Whether or not you like fashion photography underwater you would be hard pressed to see a more beautiful combination of complimentary colours and a very elegant pose. A very well executed image. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)A portrait must leave you in no doubt. Simple lighting, illuminating all that is needed, captures this character. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)Winner: Behaviour and overall winner. I worry that this image will refuel the public's imbalanced perception of sharks but as an image capturing behaviour it has drama, adrenaline, grace, beauty and finality. That's a very rare combination in one image. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Winner: Wide Angle. The first moment I viewed this image I knew it would be a strong contender. For me it's the symmetry of the Humpback and the balance between the er and calf. Everything about it is in perfect alignment. The shape of the tail in relation to the four corners of the frame, not to mention the position of the free er and calf. Superb imagery at its very best.  Many congratulations Francois. - Martin Edge (Judge)    Winner: Macro. Fabio’s use of long exposure and panning has turned a classic portrait of a Sepiola into an unforgettable one. The sharp and ghosted images of the bobtail squid balance pleasingly in the frame and combined with the outstretched tentacles give the feeling of the cephalopod lunging for its prey. An innovative and most deserving category winner. - Alex Mustard (Judge) It is hard to imagine what it must have been like to have experienced such a large scale natural spectacle as this but this image, perfectly composed and timed, gets close. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Winner: British Waters Macro. A mantra of mine is 'It's not what it is. It's where it is' and this long clawed Squat lobster is in a perfect position to make a memorable image. The author, instead of 'blasting' it with light, has gone in the opposite direction by restricting the strobe into a snooted spotlight in order to illuminate just the features of the lobster and the dainty sea loch anemones. It's an example of 'Isolation lighting' at its very best. A great deal of uw photographers invest their time in what they want to illuminate. This is an example which in my opinion illustrates features that they do not want to illuminate, hence the punchy black background and the soft delicate hues of dark sand, facial features topped off by the sea loch anemones. - Martin Edge (Judge)Winner: Marine Conservation. The problems of plastic pollution and ghost fishing are both illustrated by this struggling loggerhead turtle. I am happy to learn this inidual was lucky enough to survive this deathtrap thanks to the photographer - Alex Mustard (Judge)What a chin, what a forehead, what a character. This picture has portrait written all over it, and such a fascinating species ideally suited to this close focus wide angle approach. - Alex Mustard (Judge) Winner: Portrait. Superb impact from the very first moment it was presented. Perfect composition within the image frame and the understated colours. To top it off the authors comments above say it all... a Smiling Happy Angel's Face. One of my favourites from the entire competition. - Martin Edge (Judge)  Winner: Up &amp Coming. Beautiful split shot with both a perfect under and over split. A very strong favourite with all the judges and one of the best examples I have seen of this type of image for some time. Just Superb! - Martin Edge (Judge)Winner: Black &amp White. It must be 11 out of 10 for this groundbreaking image. Conception, interpretation and perseverance coupled with black and white’s ability to concentrate on the key elements. It gets better with each viewing. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Grey seals are a perennial favourite in UPY as one of the UK's star wildlife attractions. This upside-down portrait is quirky and cute and easily won the affections of the judging panel. Great to see an overseas photographer coming to the UK to show us how it's done! - Alex Mustard (Judge)Winner: Compact. This image was a very popular choice between the panel. Ideal for a split rendition. What makes this a winner for me, not withstanding the double exposure is the sympathetic balance of light &amp colour connected  between the top half and bottom of the image frame. - Martin Edge (Judge)Winner: British Waters Compact. Does British ing get any better than a fun encounter with a grey seal pup? This youngster’s relaxed and curious face is captured perfectly by Martin, making us all want to be there too. - Alex Mustard (Judge)Winner: British Waters Living Together. Images tell stories but well thought out and executed ones speak volumes. This is such an example which feeds the eye with tales of the seaside on summer days, lively marine spectacles and excited human interaction. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)1545 Isles of Scilly, UKWinner: British Waters Wide Angle. Photographers often feel competition shots must be packed with new tricks to win. At UPY we always appreciate classic technique when it raises the bar of what has been done before. Rob's full technicolour wide angle scenic reveals the richness of UK seas with an elegant simplicity that is incredibly challenging to pull off in British conditions. - Alex Mustard (Judge) Winner: Wrecks. So simple yet so powerful the additional lighting of the turret and the main er perfectly positioned. This was a very strong category this year with a deserved winner and it's refreshing to read the acknowledgement to Leigh Bishop's pioneering work. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) The iconic silhouette of a seahorse is a graphically powerful picture. Here Zarina has raised that to another level with the addition of a red filter to her snooted strobe, reminiscent of a rim-lit animal at sunset. - Alex Mustard (Judge) All the judges found this to be probably the most distressing image to view but its uncompromising message must be seen by as many people as possible. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)As a subject we have seen our fair share of these colourful characters but this one shone through and the eggs almost look as if they have been inidually lit! - Peter Rowlands (Judge)Superb image with a perfect line across the split. Good exposure both above and below the water line and such an ideal subject to cap it all off. Excellent work. - Martin Edge (Judge)This is an excellent example for this category. It takes a tried and trusted angle but completely lifts it by using the fabric. It becomes more than an image a concept, a transition, a rebirth. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)2245 Isles of Scilly, UKThis image stood out on many levels. Composition, colour vibrancy and contrast combined with an unusual angle kept us coming back to it and helped it rise in the rankings with each viewing. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)Perfect control of angle, light and focus. This was always up there with all of the judges. A clear favourite just like Nick Park’s genius creations. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) I've seen many images of eel and shrimp around Indonesia, however you have taken this two steps forward. 1) With your excellent idea to snoot the eye and 2) with your backlight on the shrimp. You can expect many photographers to practice your technique in the months to come. Congratulations for your vision. Very well thought out and executed. - Martin Edge (Judge)    It’s not what you’ve got, it’s what you do with it. The split may have been elusive but well worth the effort. This is a deceptively subtle excellent delivery. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)I have witnessed this behaviour from the surface with its high velocity 'testosterone and tonnage' and I remember thinking how happy I was to be in the boat. To have the presence of mind to time this shot whilst one's senses are being bombarded is heroic in my view. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) What an amazing moment. From the expression on the face of the unicornfish fleeing for its life, to the hunting pack of sharks, especially the leader with its mouth snapping open that fan out diagonally across this composition. And that is without considering what a great challenge it is to shoot these images of split second action, in the dead of night, underwater. - Alex Mustard (Judge)  There is so much energy in this image. If you look at it long enough you can begin to see just a hint of movement of all the fish around the coral. The colours are realistic and this top down shot works well.  - Martin Edge (Judge)A jaw-dropping wide angle scene with sharks, rays and mountains. A winning combination in the Up &amp Coming category. - Alex Mustard (Judge)3045 Loch Long, Argyll and ButeThis is a subtle image with light and detail that are a delight to explore. The sunset, trees and underwater scene combine to create a wonderful feeling of the place. We particularly like how the composition allows the line of the shore to be continued underwater by the seaweeds.  - Alex Mustard (Judge)Photographing pike underwater is one thing but finding your own underwater artistic stamp is quite another matter. With this particular image the author has done just that! By using a slow shutter speed of 18th sec and a panning technique from right to left gives the impression of movement whilst the pike is pin sharp. - Martin Edge (Judge)Arthur’s image scores with both its foreground and background. The deadman’s fingers soft coral make an attractive foreground, enhanced by the crab sheltering within, and the striking sunbeams create beauty and atmosphere in the background. I also love the feeling of depth created by the legs of the jetty reaching up for the surface. - Alex Mustard (Judge)In recent UPY competitions UK macro images have lacked their overseas counterpart's flair and imagination but this magnificent shot raises the bar for everyone else to follow. World class from the UK at last. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)Memorable photographs of people underwater are deceptively difficult and require both the photographer and model to be at the top of their game. The simplicity of the composition works to highlight the delicious details in the girl's pose. - Alex Mustard (Judge) This is a timeless scene that communicates a detailed story. The cavern, the silversides sheltering, the tarpon hunting and the er kneeling reverentially, taking it all in. It is a fabulous use of black and white to tell this story of shadows and light. - Alex Mustard (Judge) Sometimes it is the small detail which contributes so much. The white of the eye and the row of teeth in what could be construed as a smile convey mischief and menace in equal measures. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Once again Tobias you have succeeded in capturing one of the most photographed wrecks in the Red Sea and photographing it in a completely different way. You push the boundaries of wreck photography and I congratulate you for your vision and forward thinking of new ideas. - Martin Edge (Judge)  Perfect composition and framed against the stark black background. However it's the contrast of white on black which attracts the eye again and again every time this particular image popped up to greet us. The colour of the nudibranch was sufficiently bright enough to raise our senses again and again as it proceeded through the competition.  The soft delicate treatment of the snooted flash is also very well managed. - Martin Edge (Judge)    This shot puts you right in the picture and records a special encounter in a very special place. Every element contributes and the lucky or intended curve of the split creates great spatial depth. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Symmetry, graphic simplicity and for once in UK waters a black background which contributes to a positive outer worldly delivery. A mould breaker. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) I see and judge many images of the sockeye salmon but this is one of the best. The alignment of the two salmon not to mention the composition within the frame.  The surgy peak of the action is in perfect symmetry with the window which provides the viewer with topside influences of the trees against a vivid blue sky. But we hadn't realised during judging that this was a new species of seahorse, nor did with know the incredible backstory behind this picture, we just loved the moment. - Alex Mustard (Judge)  Whether or not you like fashion photography underwater you would be hard pressed to see a more beautiful combination of complimentary colours and a very elegant pose. A very well executed image. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)A portrait must leave you in no doubt. Simple lighting, illuminating all that is needed, captures this character. - Peter Rowlands (Judge)The footage was released on Thursday by Ningaloo Marine Interactions, the tour company which Mr Wilton works for.The hero himself suggested it was all in a day’s work.First known nursery for giant manta rays discovered in Gulf of Mexico“I’m often guiding snorkellers in the area and it’s as if she recognised me and was trusting me to help her,” he said.“She got closer and closer and then started unfurling to present the eye to me. I knew we had to get the hooks out or she would have been in big trouble. I went for a few es down to see how she’d react to me being close to her.”When the animal stayed calm, he approached and took out the hooks.The manta stayed completely still in the water,” he said.“It’s pretty incredible behaviour if this is what happened,” said David Boyle, lecturer in marine biology at the University of Plymouth. “It’s not uncommon for animals – generally mammals – to interact with ers but for one in distress to seek out assistance would be novel indeed.”Manta rays are believed to be some of the most intelligent creatures in the ocean. title: home office chief inspector borders immigration outsourcing david bolt
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsExclusive: David Bolt says subcontracting has become part of department’s ‘modus operandi’&nbsp– resulting in&nbspreduced control over its own operations and questions around accountabilityClick to followThe IndependentThe Home Office has been outsourcing&nbspimmigration operations “on the cheap” because of funding shortages and a lack of interest from ministers, the government’s own chief inspector of borders has admitted.David Bolt, who&nbspprovides&nbspindependent scrutiny of the UK’s border and immigration management, told The Independent that in order to “manage its capacity”, the Home Office had made subcontracting part of its “modus operandi” – and as a consequence had reduced control over its own operations.He questioned whether there was “sufficient visibility” around the way the department had increasingly placed the onus on external agencies,&nbspsuch as landlords and doctors,&nbspto carry out immigration checks, and around&nbspthe manner in which immigration detention,&nbspvisa processing and other provisions had been outsourced to private firms.The department&nbsphas come under fire over the past year for wrongly treating those with a&nbspright to live&nbspin the UK&nbspas illegal immigrants under its hostile environment policies&nbsp– an issue encapsulated by the Windrush scandal – and has been accused of&nbspcreating barriers to applying for UK status through its decision to privatise&nbspthe visa system.The chief inspector said that while Home Office processes that had adequate funding and “enthusiasm” from ministers were working well, such as the EU settlement scheme, other operations were not being so effectively executed.Immigration applicants forced to wait in cold after system failureMPs and lawyers call for investigation into privatised visa system“The EU settlement is working better as a process,” he said.&nbsp“You’ve got senior ministerial interest you’ve got funding the Home Office was&nbspessentially able to design the system to suit itself you’ve got enthusiasm around delivery you’ve got a clear target – all of those are ingredients that will make something work.“Much of the rest of the business doesn’t feel like that. It doesn’t have clear targets it doesn’t have the same ministerial interest it doesn’t have the funding and it’s not prioritised so it doesn’t necessarily have the resources, so I think that’s the department’s challenge.“That’s why outsourcing is part of its modus operandi. That’s one way in which it can try and manage all this capacity – to give the task to somebody else.”Mr Bolt raised concerns about difficulties for visa applicants and for other&nbspimmigrants to access the services of private firms who have commercial contracts with the Home Office, such as Sopra Steria, a French firm that took over&nbspin-country visa processing&nbspin November.The Independent revealed last month that the company had raked in millions for providing what lawyers branded a “substandard” service, which had forced some applicants to pay high fees and travel hundreds of miles to submit&nbspapplications on time.&nbspMPs and lawyers subsequently called for an independent investigation into the outsourced system, raising “extreme concerns” about Sopra Steria’s “capacity and ability” to run the service.Speaking after an event&nbsporganised by the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Visas and Immigration on Thursday, Mr Bolt said: “When you hear that people have difficulty accessing Sopra Steria or any of the other outsourced commercial contracts, what is the Home Office doing to ensure that what they’re providing is actually&nbspmeeting the terms of the contract?“In earlier contracts, one of the challenges was whether the contract had been properly funded, so there’s been an attempt to try and do things slightly on the cheap. And then it always feels rather reluctant to press the provider, because they realised they’ve got the provider over a barrel.“The question is, does it retain sufficient visibility of what’s going on and sufficient control over it? And to what extent is it accountable for what’s delivered?”A report published by Mr Bolt&nbspin 2016, which aimed to understand how the Home Office was going to assess the effectiveness of the&nbsphostile environment policies, found there were “no real measurements in place to collect, analyse and evaluate” the measures.But the chief inspector questioned whether the department had “the capacity to do anything about it” because they were “short of resource generally, meaning everything is under pressure” – likening the situation to “changing a tyre as you’re driving down the motorway”.“Across all of the Home Office, its business is bigger than its capacity to manage. It’s constantly having to make decisions about priorities, and getting dragged off to do things. That for me is one of the key issues – whether it’s got the bandwidth to cope with everything,” he added.A Home Office spokesperson said:&nbsp“We welcome the independent scrutiny of the chief inspector and take his comments, criticism and recommendations very seriously.&nbsp“We are committed to delivering an immigration system that is fair and delivers value for money for the taxpayer and the inspector is a crucial part of that work. It is only right that the department and ministers give full consideration to the recommendations made in ICIBI&nbsp(independent chief inspector of borders and immigration)&nbspreports, which can be complex and wide-ranging.”Asylum and Immigration&nbsp|&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: brexit no deal job losses greg clark economy bank of england
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Politics Explained:&nbspThe business secretary says ‘many thousands’ will be left unemployed if Britain crashes out of the EUClick to followIndy PoliticsGreg Clark, the business secretary, reiterated warnings that a no-deal Brexit would trigger many thousands of job losses.“Everyone knows that”, he told Sky News. “I think that every person who considers the evidence that companies have given, whether it’s in the automotive sector, whether it’s in the food sector, whether it’s in aerospace, whether it’s in industries up and down the country.”But is he right and what might happen to jobs if the UK crashes out of the EU without a deal?The economy will certainly take a hit which almost all analysts predict will ultimately result in firms shedding staff. First of all, the pound is likely to drop significantly against other major currencies, as happened in the aftermath of the 2016 referendum.‘Many thousands’ of jobs lost in no-deal Brexit, minister warnsThis will rapidly increase the cost of imported raw materials and components at the same time as businesses have to deal with disruptions to their supply chain as the free movement of goods and services ends abruptly.Additional tariffs will further add to the cost of doing business as will non-tariff barriers such as customs checks, additional paperwork and quotas.Some businesses, such as those which rely heavily on sourcing parts from across the continent, will become unprofitable and inevitably have to lay off staff or even shut down completely.We have a number of forecasts of what this might mean for employment.In December, academics at the University of Sussex predicted that a no-deal scenario will cost 750,000 UK jobs, including 150,000 in London and over 80,000 in the northwest of England.Analysis by Cambridge Econometrics commissioned by the mayor of London forecasts 87,000 jobs lost in the capital by 2030 out of a nationwide total of half a million.Across the EU, around 1.2 million jobs would be lost, according to a recent paper from the University of Leuven. It concluded that Ireland, Belgium and the Netherlands would be the worst affected by a no-deal Brexit, with Dublin losing 50,330 jobs or 2.6 per cent of its entire workforce.This week the Northern Irish government sounded the alarm with a warning that the country would lose 40,000 jobs after a no-deal Brexit, primarily as a result of disruptions to trade with the Republic.While there is considerable variation in the predictions, all certainly support the business secretary’s assertion.The Bank of England’s Gertjan Vlieghe pointed to a further problem on Friday: that British workers,&nbsphighly indebted and with low levels of savings, are ill-equipped to deal with the sudden slump in the labour market that Brexit may bring.“I remain concerned about the vulnerability of households to a downside surprise in income or employment, given the very low savings rate,” said Mr Vlieghe, who sits on the BoE’s interest rate-setting committee.The latest news on Brexit direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsImmigrants who've been given orders to leave the country are government targets in at least 10 major citiesClick to followThe Independent USThe Trump administration’s immigration crackdown is under way today - targeting migrant families in major cities across the country.Sweeps had been expected to start on Sunday, but New York City mayor Bill de Blasio tweeted on Saturday that the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency had already taken action in New York.He said they had targeted Brooklyn’s Sunset Park and parts of Harlem, but had been unsuccessful in detaining anyone. He says he has refused too co-operate with ICE.Immigrant communities have been on edge since President Donald Trump's administration announced plans for the operation, with some going to extreme lengths to avoid being deported.There were reports of some families stockpiling food and drawing the curtains, while others pinned notices to the inside of their front doors with legal advice on what to do if enforcement agents came knocking.Created with Sketch. However, India postponed the launch.After that the rover will analyse minerals, map rock formations on the surface and search for water.&nbspThe lunar south pole is especially interesting because a much larger portion of it is in shadow than the north pole, presenting a greater possibility of water.Water is an essential ingredient for life, and finding it is part of science’s broader goal of determining whether there is life elsewhere in our solar system.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Apollo 11's historic first moon landing - In pictures Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Edwin 'Buzz' Aldrin walking on the moon in an iconic image taken by 'Apollo 11' commander and first man on the moon, Neil Armstrong, on 20 July 1969. 2019 marks the 50th anniversary of the first moon landing, an event seen as the peak of the United States' space program of the 1960s which put an end to the so-called 'Race to Space' between the Cold War rivals the US and the Soviet Union. title: ursula von der leyen eu commission president vote backing pass
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Politics Explained: She faces a vote on Tuesday, and it’s not a sure thingClick to followThe IndependentEU leaders may have picked Ursula von der Leyen as their choice for European&nbspCommission president after a series of late-night summits –&nbspbut she’s not there yet.The German defence minister has to be approved by the European parliament before she gets the post, and it’s not looking like plain sailing.If MEPs reject Von der Leyen then member states will have to go back to the drawing board and propose another candidate.The nominee has been talking to the EU’s different political groups trying to convince them, and she’s not had much luck so far.The left group was first out the gate to say it&nbspwould not vote for her –&nbspthis was mostly expected.Then, the Greens –&nbspwho made significant gains at the elections, yet were excluded from the nominations for the top jobs –&nbspalso said they couldn’t support her.&nbspThey could have their revenge.New EU commission cabinet will be half women, says Juncker replacementUrsula von der Leyen: the German minister set to run the EUEU leaders back Ursula von der Leyen to be commission presidentOn Thursday evening, the socialist group – the parliament’s centre-left, and its second largest band of MEPs – said it couldn’t vote for Von der Leyen at this point and outlined its concerns to her in a letter.This is where things start to get extremely tricky, and the numbers start to look very tight. The socialists did not rule out voting for her, but have basically laid out a programme of things she needs to agree to to get their support.&nbspTheir demands – it’s a very long list – include an investment programme, opening accession talks with Albania and North Macedonia in 2019, and reform of EU foreign policy. It’s not quite clear how serious they are about all the policies, many of which have been knocking around for ages.The liberal group, which is now called Renew, has also sent a similar letter.Von der Leyen needs 374 votes in the 751-member parliament to win: without the support of the socialist and the liberals – the latter of which have kept quiet for now – she has to rely on Eurosceptic groups to vote for her.Created with Sketch.World news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Japan's Megumu Yoshida and Yukiko Inui compete in the duet technical artistic swimming event during the 2019 World Championships at Yeomju Gymnasium in GwangjuHot air balloons fly over the city of Igualada during an early flight as part of the European Balloon Festival in Igualada, Spain. Israeli police Friday morning shot and killed a Palestinian young man following an alleged stabbing attack in Jerusalemâ€™s Old City. title: tunisia lgbt gay president candidate mounir baatour shams
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the options'I was jailed for three months for sodomy in 2013. There’s no shame for me. There’s no shame for any of us,' says Mounir BaatourClick to followThe IndependentMounir Baatour’s office is cool, the steady thrum of the air conditioner offering a welcome break from the blistering summer heat that has descended upon Tunis. Past noon, little moves outside. The streets are empty and even the city’s ubiquitous cat population has slinked off to the shadows.Despite the temperature, Baatour, the first openly gay man to run for president in a Muslim country, remains focused upon the task ahead.The road leading to the November poll is unlikely to offer a smooth ride. Homosexuality itself isn’t illegal in Tunisia. However, practising it is. This distinction has allowed Baatour, a lawyer, to register the pressure group&nbspShams. Along with others, the group campaigns for a repeal of the colonial French&nbsplaw&nbspproscribing sodomy.Likewise, legal&nbsprestrictions criminalising&nbsp”outrages against public decency” are often used to persecute the country’s LGBT+ population – these&nbspremain firmly with the sights of Baatour and other rights campaigners. &nbsp&nbspOn top of this, the police force appears eager to exploit existing edicts allowing, for instance,&nbspenforced anal examinations to be used as evidence of sexuality. This is buttressed by a judiciary and political establishment long practised in the art of looking the other way.Created with Sketch.Best photos from Pride 2019 around the world Show all 45Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.In February, a young man from the coastal city of Sfax received an eight month&nbspsentence for engaging in homosexual acts after reporting being raped by two other men. Other stories of official abuse are legion. &nbsp&nbsp“I am openly gay,”&nbspBaatour&nbspsays. “I came out 20 years ago. I was jailed for three months for sodomy in 2013. There’s no shame for me. There’s no shame for any of us.”Baatour, his association and his relatively fringe Liberal party are children of Tunisia’s revolution. In the years immediately following 2011, a number of gay rights groups emerged, led by Baatour’s own Shams, calling for a repeal of&nbspanti-homosexual laws.However, even here, Shams’ tactics have given rise to ision, with a coalition for LGBT+ rights issuing a statement&nbsplast year distancing themselves from Shams and its president. Baatour attributes this schism to his openness to potentially normalising relations with Israel, a suggestion considered anathema to many on Tunisia’s left.Perhaps ironically, the same period during which many of these groups arose also witnessed an explosion in Islamism across Tunisia, with the moderate Islamist Ennahda party vying with the radical&nbspAnsar al-Sharia&nbspfor the political souls of Tunisia’s religious majority.When you put gay people in jail for three years, what, do they come out straight? No&nbspAnsar&nbspal-Sharia was outlawed in 2013, and support for Ennahda appears to have ebbed since the groundswell of popular support that saw them achieve a plurality vote in the country’s first free elections in 2011.But across many sections of Tunisian society, values typically bend towards the traditional. In August, conservative demonstrators of both genders took to the street to protest a&nbsppresidentially mandated report&nbspurging greater inidual freedoms and equality across the genders. &nbspAs far as homosexuality is concerned, those conservative sentiments cut deeper. A June 2019 survey by the polling institute Arab Barometer reported that just 7 per cent of Tunisians condoned homosexuality. It’s a sentiment reflected within the rhetoric of some of Baatour’s populist rivals for the presidency. Law professor Kais Saied&nbspis&nbspa close second in the polls – he has&nbspsuggested&nbspthat encouraging the spread of homosexuality within the country is a foreign plot. &nbsp &nbsp &nbspAlleged rape victim imprisoned for homosexual acts by Tunisian court“I think we need to have a debate about homosexuality in Tunisia,” says Baatour, who identifies as Muslim but doesn’t practise.“I’m not talking about promoting homosexuality, just about decriminalising it. Gay people don’t do anyone any harm. They should be free to do what they want with their bodies. If, as Kais Saied has said, homosexuality is a sickness, then – even if I accept that – I have to ask, why are you putting sick people in jail?“When you put gay people in jail for three years, what, do they come out straight? No. So they must return to jail for a further three years and then for the rest of their lives.”Though what Baatour is proposing might seem radical, it is not without precedent. In arguing his case, Baatour points to the country’s first post-independence president, Habib Bourguiba, who in 1956 introduced landmark laws outlawing polygamy and introducing a code of women’s rights that stands to this day.LGBT activists arrested at unauthorised pride march in Cuba“All of that at the time was controversial, a lot of people said it was against Islam. However, Bourguiba had the political will to impose it. In 1956, Tunisia was more conservative than it is now, but people came to accept it and still do.” &nbspHowever, while accepting that much of the attention on him focuses upon his stance on LGBT+ rights, Baatour is keen to stress that his candidacy is about more.He wants to address many of Tunisia’s underlying ills, from the state enterprises that continue to haemorrhage money, to the vast scale of the country’s informal economy, to the environment, which remains a priority.But above all, he says, is his commitment to promoting civil liberties and the rights of the inidual.Whether or not he is successful remains to be seen. However, for Baatour, the fight alone is worthwhile. If anything, he says, his campaign forces the other candidates to address the lack of progress on civil liberties and inidual rights within Tunisia.Baatour leans forward, “I will place this at the very heart of my campaign.”Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: sir kim darroch departure necessary
story: As soon as President Trump announced he wouldn’t be speaking to our man in Washington, there regrettably wasn’t anything he could realistically do. As he himself said, his job had become “impossible”.But this whole episode has been utterly depressing, and there is plenty of blame to go around.Perhaps Sir Kim was a little loose in his language, but no diplomat could ever expect his confidential notes to senior figures in London to end up on the front of the papers.The tributes since his resignation certainly suggest that this was the first time he’d put a foot even slightly wrong in his entire career.And the President — who is a friend of Britain — should have realised that when it comes to diplomacy, the shoot-from-the-hip style he uses on social media can have consequences.No newspaper complains about a leak, but whoever undermined Sir Kim by releasing his not-quite-diplomatic cables should reflect on the damage it has done to not just our international standing but to the Foreign Office’s ability to do its job.As for the Boris “row”, it’s unedying to see his detractors weaponising this sorry saga against him.Whatever he had said on the TV debate, Sir Kim’s position was already sadly untenable.Moving forward, the Special Relationship must remain special.Our links with America are stronger than one ambassador, from security to our shared culture.But we must never be complacent about the ties to our closest ally.YOU can see why Labour has turned on the journalists behind last night’s Panorama investigation into the party’s dreadful handling of anti-Semitism in its ranks.The programme was damning from start to finish. It details the most extraordinary levels of racism in all corners of the party and a total refusal of the leadership to do anything about it.Indeed the party appears to have actually tried to strangle worthwhile investigations at birth, and to have actively interfered in the disciplinary process.Corbyn’s useful idiots have predictably turned on the whistleblowers – ironic, considering Labour’sShadow Chancellor once handed a petition to No calling for better protection for those brave enough to call their employers out for bad practice.Hypocrites, the lot of them.It may not be the case that Corbyn himself is a racist, but goodness, he does seem to attract an awful lot of them — and be too thick or ignorant to notice they’re there.The party’s rotten, from top to bottom.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mps lords houses in order karren brady
story: Nearly two years on from #MeToo, two new reports paint a bleak picture of sexual harassment in Westminster.The first report, about the House of Lords, found that one in five peers was considered to behave in an inappropriate or high-handed way to staff. One Lord was described as a “notorious bullying pervert” by a Westminster worker.The verdict was that the prevailing culture and behaviour in the House of Lords “has not been conducive to an open and supportive culture to ensure all those working there are treated with dignity and respect”.Worse, the report concluded those staff on the receiving end of bullying and harassment generally did not complain because they thought nothing would change, or feared reprisal.Clearly, the House of Lords has issues. But it’s nowhere near as bad as the House of Commons. The second report, by Gemma White QC into inappropriate conduct in Westminster, concluded MPs’ staff face “unacceptable risk of bullying and harassment”.It found sexual harassment in Parliament is seen by young staff as a “necessary evil”they want to progress. Witnesses describe speaking out against any abuse as “career suicide”.Even though both reports state only a small minority of MPs or Lords behave in unacceptable ways, this has been tolerated for too long and shining a light on it will bring about change.What’s clear to me, both from reading the report and working at the House of Lords, is that this is a generational issue. The House of Lords is full of older people stuck in a time warp.Many of them live in a world where it’s still acceptable for women — often females of a lower status to them — to be patted on the bottom or on the head.The House of Lords can feel a bit like a boys’ boarding school, or Hogwarts. It’s populated predominantly by old white men, many of whom lead a le insulated from the real world.That said, the worst behaviour I witness is usually in the library, where Lords often retire after lunch and which rings with the sound of ear-deafening snoring and, I am sorry to say, farting.The only time I’ve ever seen anyone being actively rude was when one Lord commanded a member of canteen staff to get him a bag of crisps. He was so close he could have reached out and got it himself.I’ve also been on the receiving end of the odd condescending comment, such as when a Lord looked me up and down and said: “You’re dressed rather casually.” I was wearing Stella McCartney trousers at the time, so not exactly jeans.Crucially, though, I wasn’t wearing a dress. So I looked him up and down and said: “Dressing casually is better than dressing badly” — and that was the end of that.It must be horrible to work in an organisation where you feel inferior and can’t speak your mind — and,you do, people either shrug or shut you down. The report about the House of Lords suggested it should be mandatory for all employees to go on a “how to value people” course. Some people might see it as unnecessary — but we send West Ham staff on them and they are good.But that’s not the only change required. There’s neither enough women, nor cultural ersity. The only way that will change is by electing a more erse chamber.In the meantime, I hope this report does not diminish, in people’s minds, the important legislation work the House of Lords does and the role it plays in holding the Commons to account. story: NewsHelp to Buy builder Persimmon Homes exposed as worst in UK after investigationThe scandal is exposed in Monday night’s Dispatches programme on Channel ShareCommentsByMatthew Young:,  JUL NewsPersimmon Homes made a pre-tax profit of £bn last year "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritainaposs most profitable housebuilder has been branded the worst within the Help to Buy scheme. title: emily thornberry wades soap opera
story: NewsEmily Thornberry wades into soap opera over Labour anti-Semitism and BBC PanoramaEmily Thornberry criticised Labour chiefs for "going for" staff whistleblowers - but also had stern words for deputy leader Tom WatsonShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JUL NewsEmily Thornberry said it was wrong for Labour “go for” former officials who blew the whistle "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The bitter fallout from an explosive documentary about Labour ’s handling of anti-Semitism and the treatment of staff continued to rage today.Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry said it was wrong for Labour “go for” former officials who blew the whistle on the party’s handling of complaints. But she dismissed the public infighting over the Panorama investigation as a “soap opera”.It comes as two whistleblowers featured in the BBC programme said they now plan to sue the party.Sam Matthews and Louise Withers Green have instructed high profile media lawyer Mark Lewis to act on their behalf because they believed the party had defamed them in its response to their claims.Labour continues to complain about the documentary, which claimed that senior figures - including Jeremy Corbyn ’s communications chief Seumas Milne and general secretary Jennie Formby - had interfered in anti-Semitism investigations. Addressing the Durham Miners’ Gala on Saturday, Mr Corbyn said the documentary had contained “many, many inaccuracies”. However, in an interview with BBC One’s The Andrew Marr Show, Ms Thornberry said the party needs to face up to the fact that it still has a problem with anti-Semitism. “I think that we shouldn’t be going for the messengers, we should be looking at the message. I think that is a mistake,” she said.  “She is the general secretary of the Labour Party but we know that she is very ill. I think it is completely inappropriate to personalise this.” Her comments followed an angry tirade from Unite union general secretary Len McCluskey, who said Mr Watson “and his pals” should “f****** well be ashamed of yourselves”. To cheers from the crowd at Durham Racecourse, he declared: “Jennie, our message to you is that the Durham Miners’ Gala stands with you.” “I don’t care about the soap opera, I care that I have a Jewish member of staff, who when she goes to family weddings, can’t say who she works for, even though I fight on this issue a lot, she cannot say who she works for or what she does, because she doesn’t want to spend the rest of the day defending herself,” Thornberry told BBC One’s The Andew Marr Show. title: kevin maguire labour must remain

title: dark fascination knives ended grammar
story: NewsDark fascination with knives that ended grammar school pupil Yousef Makkis leYousef Makkis death in a leafy suburban Manchester street has revealed a disturbing culture of kne crime among youngsters with social privilegeShareByJohn ScheerhoutChris Osuh:,  JUL NewsYousef had been thriving at Manchester Grammar School "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYousef Makki was a bright and ambitious boy. He seemed destined to defy his ordinary beginnings as the son of an immigrant raised in a terraced home in the Greater Manchester  suburb of Burnage. Yousef’s father Ghaleb left his home in Beirut  years ago with nothing. He moved to England hoping for a new and better le. He and his we Debbie had high hopes for their bookish, bespectacled son Yousef, who passed the entrance exam for the elite Manchester Grammar School, one of the nation’s most successful. But that all ended in March this year, in a death which showed a disturbing culture of kne crime among youngsters who have social privilege, reports the Manchester Evening News.  Aged , Yousef must have felt intimidated when he first walked the cloistered corridors and looked up at the pictures of MGS alumni, like Oscar-winning actor Ben Kingsley, Nobel-prize winning chemist John Polanyi and England cricket captain Michael Atherton, amid a long list of celebrated writers, historians and musicians, many of them knights of the realm. This was a world away from Beirut, the place he proudly considered his spiritual home, all his short le. Greater Manchester was supposed to be safer place to grow up than Beirut. Unlike the majority of pupils at MGS whose families paid the £,-a-year fees, Yousef was given a bursary because of his parents’ relatively small income, and grew up close to the Fallowfield school. Without that financial help, he would not have been able to attend. Academically, the young Yousef thrived in his early years at MGS, routinely getting top grades and, like many aspirational boys at the school, dreamed of studying medicine. He was excelling at his A levels: maths, economics, chemistry and biology.  And, while no-one suggests his school was in any way at fault, there is a tragic irony in Yousefaposs story. Many parents might imagine that a place at an expensive private school would be the surest way of protecting their son or daughter from bad influences and bad choices. How many parents would fear their child would never come home while socialising in Hale Barns, one of the wealthiest parts of Greater Manchester  But thataposs precisely what happened to Yousef Makki. Privileged boys with double lives Following a three-week trial, a -year-old boy, identied for legal reasons as Boy One, has been cleared of murder, manslaughter and a conspiracy to rob said to have led to Yousefaposs death, while a second -year-old, known as Boy Two, has been cleared of conspiracy to rob and perverting the course of justice.  The verdicts mean no-one is criminally responsible for Yousefaposs death. However, the trial that led to this conclusion revealed that Yousef and the two boys - who he was with on the night of his death - were living double lives. Like many teenagers Yousef experimented with cannabis. As did Boy One and Two. Had the experimentation ended there, Yousef might still be alive, and the other two might never have appeared in a crown court on serious charges. But there was also a disturbing fascination with knives. Boy One repeatedly filmed himself playing with knives, listened to tracks that celebrated knives and kne crime, and looked at knives on Instagram.  Boy Two filmed himself brandishing a flick-kne, and sent the video to Yousef. aposBanterapos about knives and stabbing featured in Yousefaposs banter with both boys. In the trial that followed his death, Boy One admitted that he aposliked to carryapos a blade, he said to avoid being mugged. Boy Two said he carried one to aposfit inapos, despite the fact neither boy lived in a high crime area, or fitted the social profile of a youngster particularly at risk of gang or kne crime. They claimed Yousef had a kne too, though he isnapost here to defend himself. As Boy Oneaposs barrister put it, it was about acting tough aposon the streets of Wilmslowapos, adding: “Whataposs going on with this generation of children with the advantage of good families and a good education and clearly materially well off   They appeared to have led double lives, living out idiotic fantasies.” It all came to a head on March , when the trio were hanging round in Hale Barns, smoking cannabis. Grainy CCTV from a shop picked them up. Yousef shadow-boxing, the two others showing off the flick-knives they had bought online,  the trio having idled up to the car park on bikes, all three of them apparently stoned. Had this been a poorer part of south Manchester, the scene - knives, bikes, cannabis - could easily have seen them branded as gang members. Except this was Hale Barns. Boy One was on £, bike, and the shop they were outside was the high-end grocery chain, Booths, rather than a corner off-licence.  From the car park of Booths the trio rode to get £ worth of cannabis at a rendezvous on Sunbank Lane. And what happened there was was the trigger for Yousefaposs death - and the event that would leave his two friends facing serious charges. Boy One ended up being beaten up by two of the alleged drug dealeraposs mates. The prosecutionaposs claim that this was after Boy One had tried and failed to rob the alleged dealer, having conspired with Boy Two to do it, a version of events that was rejected by the jury. In his defence, Boy One said the motive for the attack on him was because he had been wrongly blamed for an assault on one of their associates.  And he claimed that none of his friends helped him when he was attacked, his prized bike thrown over a hedge. Yousef had merely watched, he said, while Boy Two had run off.  minutes later, Yousef was bleeding to death at Gorse Bank Road, Hale Barns. Boy One, describing the moments before Yousef was fatally injured  - by his flick-kne - said there was a confrontation after he told Yousef and Boy Two that he was going home. “I just wanted to find my bike so that we are all on good terms. I wasn’t having it. I really wanted to go home. I started to get more adamant, more angry so I said f*** off I’m going home.” “Then I believe Yousef got a bit annoyed and called me a p**sy. I got annoyed at this. I was the only one standing there who had got a beating while one of your friends runs off and the other one just watches.”  Asked how he felt at being called a p**sy, he said: “I didn’t think it was fair. I said how am I a p**syI’m stood there taking a beating whilst you two have done nothing  This is when I have pushed Yousef. It was just out of frustration. It was just with an open palm. It wasn’t like full force. It was more I’m not in a mood, leave me alone, go away.” Boy One said Yousef ‘got a bit annoyed about that’ and punched him, with one blow landing on the right side of his head. “I was just kind of a bit confused. I wasn’t really expecting it, Boy One went on. And then I have looked up and Yousef is quite annoyed at me at this point. I believe I saw him, he had taken his kne out and he looked like he was going to hit me again saying ‘come on, come on’. Claiming that he ‘just didn’t want to get beaten up again’ and that he felt ‘quite on edge’, Boy One went on.  ”I have started to take a kne out of my pocket,” he said, describing how he removed the blade from the right pocket of his gilet. He said he couldnapost remember whether the blade was out of his flick-kne, saying it happened in a matter of seconds and that Yousef was less than a metre away. Asked what his intention in producing the kne was, he replied: “I donapost know, I just, just to warn him off, trying to get him to leave me alone.” So how did the blade end up in Yousefaposs chest, penetrating his ribs, going into his heart  Did Boy One know  “Not really, he told his trial. I do not know what I did. I don’t know how it all came together ... I really didn’t think it was anything at first. I didn’t think I had stabbed him. “I kind of stood back a bit and walked away and then Yousef pulls out and says’ you’ve stabbed me.  In the  seconds afterwards Boy One discarded his kne in a hedge, before bumping into a private security officer, Michael Bowman. Bowman was paid to patrol the leafy avenues, and had seen a commotion about m away from his car. I need your help, my mateaposs been stabbed, Boy One said. Yousef lay by a tree, blood pumping from his chest wound onto the grass verge. Boy Two made two  calls at once - one from his own phone, the other from Yousef’s blood-stained device, which the dying teenager struggled to unlock. My mateaposs been stabbed yeah, he needs an ambulance here now. Heaposs going to die, please hurry up, hurry up please. Hurry up bro, Boy Two told the operator. title: how richest man history made
story: NewsHow richest man in history made his billions - and family heartbreak that went with itJohn Davison Rockefeller was the wealthiest man of his time and arguably of ALL time, and he was four times richer that Bill Gates is todayShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL News "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailItaposs the family name that conjures up visions of vast wealth, power, and political intrigue – Rockefeller. An American dynasty built on “black gold” oil would become one of the richest and most influential in history, while experiencing a wealth of tragedies too. Yet when founder John Davison Rockefeller began his working le aged , his dream was to make just , dollars and live to be . Heaposd done a ten week course in accounting and been toughened up by his con-artist father who boasted “I cheat my boys every chance I get. I want to make aposem sharp.” Yet just  years later John D, Rockefeller, born appropriately in a town called Richford, New York, had become Americaaposs first billionaire.  He founded Standard Oil with his younger brother William and the eventually commanded a monopoly controlling  per cent of all Americaaposs oil. By the time John died in  - three years short of his centenary - he was the wealthiest man of his time and arguably of ALL time. His assets equalled .% of America’s TOTAL economic output - thataposs  billion dollars in todayaposs terms. So John D Rockefeller was more than four times richer that Bill Gates is today.    He retired in his late s and spent the final  years of his le enjoying the trappings of success, notably through a string of remarkable properties such as Kykuit, a six-storey home he built on the vast Westchester County estate and a -room holiday home called The Eyrie on Maine’s Mount Desert Island. He also had a huge mansion on West th Street in New York – the site now occupied by the Museum of Modern Art which, was co-founded by his granddaughter, Abby Rockefeller. In the s his son, John D Jr, also built the famous Rockefeller Center comprising  skyscrapers in Manhattan.  John Jraposs son David became a powerful banker.But the tycoon’s true legacy was the remarkable philanthropy that saw him give away more than  billion to worthy causes, ranging from medical research to education. He is said to be the biggest medical benefactor in history. His flagship company was broken up in  but the Rockefeller family – which today has  members - is still worth more than  billion and has interests around the globe.We look at some of the shocking secrets of the super-rich Rockefellers. William Avery Rockefeller, John D.’s father, posed as a “deaf-mute peddler” to sell miracle potions and herbal remedies. Nicknamed “Devil Bill,” he also posed as an eye and ear specialist named Dr. William Levingston.    He had children with both his we and mistress, the latter woman living with the family as their housekeeper. Nelson Rockefeller John Daposs grandson, was a businessman turned politician and Governor of New York from -. When Gerald Ford took over from shamed President Richard Nixon on  he appointed Rockefeller Vice President. But five years later he died from a heart attack at the age of . Rockefeller Center security were said to have found him dead at his desk. But later reports issued a correction the -year-old actually died a townhouse, where he was having sex with a -year-old aide. Nelson’s family contested this, but a longtime aide confirmed the affair. Dr Richard Rockefeller, son of David and nephew of Nelson, devoted his le to philanthropy, rather than banking or politics. Tragically, he died aged , when his plane hit fog and crashed outside Harrison, New York. The  flight had taken off from the nearby Rockefeller estate. Winston Churchill almost wrote the Rockefeller story. The future Prime Minister wrote more than  books, earning the  Nobel Prize for Literature.  But in the s, the Rockefellers asked Winston to write John D.’s authorized biography. But he wanted a , advance. Even the wealthiest family in the world wasn’t willing to pay it, so they hired a Columbia University historian instead. In , Nelsons fth son traveled to New Guinea. Michael C Rockefeller,  was photographer and trustee of the Museum of Primitive Art an hoped to bring an indigenous art collection back to New York. When his boat overturned, however, he tried to swim to shore and get help but despite a two-week search, he was never found. Although his official cause of death is drowning, many think he was eaten by a crocodile or shark. Some rumours suggested he made it to shore. And a month later, a Dutch priest spoke with men from the Otsjanep tribe, who admitted they killed a man who matched Michael’s description. They even showed the priest some bones. Rumours circulated that he had been eaten. John D. Rockefeller Sr.’s great-niece killed herself and her two daughters.
